natural problem: How many distinct three-digit positive integers have only odd digits?
natural solution: There are 5 odd digits, and thus, each digit has 5 different possibilities, making for $5^3 = \boxed{125}$ possibilities.

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes odd_digits :: "nat set"
assumes h0 : "odd_digits = {1, 3, 5, 7, 9}"
and h1 : "card {n. n \<ge> 100 \<and> n < 1000 \<and> (\<forall> d. d \<in> set (digits n) \<longrightarrow> d \<in> odd_digits)} = 125"
shows  "card {n. n \<ge> 100 \<and> n < 1000 \<and> (\<forall> d. d \<in> set (digits n) \<longrightarrow> d \<in> odd_digits)} = 125"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 How many distinct three-digit positive integers have only odd digits? The final Answer is 125
 ### Proof
 There are 5 odd digits, and thus, each digit has 5 different possibilities, making for $5^3 = \boxed{125}$ possibilities.
 *)

theorem
fixes odd_digits :: "nat set"
assumes h0 : "odd_digits = {1, 3, 5, 7, 9}"
and h1 : "card {n. n \<ge> 100 \<and> n < 1000 \<and> (\<forall> d. d \<in> set (digits n) \<longrightarrow> d \<in> odd_digits)} = 125"
shows  "card {n. n \<ge> 100 \<and> n < 1000 \<and> (\<forall> d. d \<in> set (digits n) \<longrightarrow> d \<in> odd_digits)} = 125"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: How many three-digit numbers are there such that all their digits are odd? The final answer is 125.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes num :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> n. num n = card {i. i \<ge> 100 \<and> i \<le> 999 \<and> (\<forall> d. d = i mod 10 \<or> d = (i div 10) mod 10 \<or> d = i div 100 \<longrightarrow> odd d)}"
shows  "num 1 = 125"
a_1.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 How many distinct three-digit positive integers have only odd digits? The final Answer is 125
 ### Proof
 There are 5 odd digits, and thus, each digit has 5 different possibilities, making for $5^3 = \boxed{125}$ possibilities.
 *)

theorem
fixes num :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> n. num n = card {i. i \<ge> 100 \<and> i \<le> 999 \<and> (\<forall> d. d = i mod 10 \<or> d = (i div 10) mod 10 \<or> d = i div 100 \<longrightarrow> odd d)}"
shows  "num 1 = 125"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem: How many 3-digit numbers have all their digits odd? The final answer is 125.

a_2.formal problem:
theorem
fixes count_odd_digits :: "int \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "\<forall>n. count_odd_digits n = card {d. d \<in> {1, 3, 5, 7, 9} \<and> d is a digit of n}"
shows  "card {n. 100 \<le> n \<and> n < 1000 \<and> count_odd_digits n = 3} = 125"
a_2.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 How many distinct three-digit positive integers have only odd digits? The final Answer is 125
 ### Proof
 There are 5 odd digits, and thus, each digit has 5 different possibilities, making for $5^3 = \boxed{125}$ possibilities.
 *)

shows  "card {n. 100 \<le> n \<and> n < 1000 \<and> count_odd_digits n = 3} = 125"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer

a_3.formal problem:
theorem odd_digits_count:
fixes n :: nat
assumes h0 : "100 \<le> n \<and> n \<le> 999"
and h1 : "\<forall>d. d \<in> digits n \<longrightarrow> odd d"
shows  "card {n. 100 \<le> n \<and> n \<le> 999 \<and> (\<forall>d. d \<in> digits n \<longrightarrow> odd d)} = 125"
a_3.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 How many distinct three-digit positive integers have only odd digits? The final Answer is 125
 ### Proof

 *)

a_4.formal problem:

fixes count_odd_digits :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "count_odd_digits n = card {x. x \<in> {100..999} \<and> (\<forall> d \<in> set (digits n). odd d)}"
shows  "count_odd_digits 3 = 125"

 proof-

a_5.formal problem:
theorem
fixes n :: nat
assumes h0 : "\<forall> n. (100 \<le> n \<and> n \<le> 999) \<longrightarrow> (\<forall> d. (d = 1 \<or> d = 3 \<or> d = 5 \<or> d = 7 \<or> d = 9) \<longrightarrow> (\<forall> p. 0 \<le> p \<and> p < 3 \<longrightarrow> d = n div (10^p) mod 10))"
shows  "card {n. \<forall> d p. (100 \<le> n \<and> n \<le> 999) \<and> (d = 1 \<or> d = 3 \<or> d = 5 \<or> d = 7 \<or> d = 9) \<and> (0 \<le> p \<and> p < 3) \<and> (d = n div (10^p) mod 10)} = 125"
a_5.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 How many distinct three-digit positive integers have only odd digits? The final Answer is 125
 ### Proof
 There are 5 odd digits, and thus, each digit has 5 different possibilities, making for $5^3 = \boxed{125}$ possibilities.
 *)

theorem
fixes n :: nat
assumes h0 : "\<forall> n. (100 \<le> n \<and> n \<le> 999) \<longrightarrow> (\<forall> d. (d = 1 \<or> d = 3 \<or> d = 5 \<or> d = 7 \<or> d = 9) \<longrightarrow> (\<forall> p. 0 \<le> p \<and> p < 3 \<longrightarrow> d = n div (10^p) mod 10))"
shows  "card {n. \<forall> d p. (100 \<le> n \<and> n \<le> 999) \<and> (d = 1 \<or> d = 3 \<or> d = 5 \<or> d = 7 \<or> d = 9) \<and> (0 \<le> p \<and> p < 3) \<and> (d = n div (10^p) mod 10)} = 125"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_5.informal problem: How many three-digit numbers have all their digits odd (1, 3, 5, 7, or 9)? The final answer is 125.

theorem
fixes count_odd_digits :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "\<forall>n. count_odd_digits n = card {x. x \<ge> 1 \<and> x < 10 \<and> x mod 2 = 1}"
shows  "card {x. x \<ge> 100 \<and> x \<le> 999 \<and> (\<forall>i. i \<in> set (digits x) \<longrightarrow> i mod 2 = 1)} = 125"
a_6.formal solution:

a_8.formal problem:
theorem odd_digits_count:
fixes count_odd_digits :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "\<forall>n. n \<ge> 100 \<and> n \<le> 999 \<and> (\<forall>d. d \<in> set (digits n) \<longrightarrow> odd d) \<longrightarrow> count_odd_digits n = 1"
and h1 : "\<forall>n. n < 100 \<or> n > 999 \<or> (\<exists>d. d \<in> set (digits n) \<and> even d) \<longrightarrow> count_odd_digits n = 0"
shows  "(\<Sum>n = 100..999. count_odd_digits n) = 125"
a_8.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 How many distinct three-digit positive integers have only odd digits? The final Answer is 125
 ### Proof
 There are 5 odd digits, and thus, each digit has 5 different possibilities, making for $5^3 = \boxed{125}$ possibilities.
 *)

theorem odd_digits_count:
fixes count_odd_digits :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "\<forall>n. n \<ge> 100 \<and> n \<le> 999 \<and> (\<forall>d. d \<in> set (digits n) \<longrightarrow> odd d) \<longrightarrow> count_odd_digits n = 1"
and h1 : "\<forall>n. n < 100 \<or> n > 999 \<or> (\<exists>d. d \<in> set (digits n) \<and> even d) \<longrightarrow> count_odd_digits n = 0"
shows  "(\<Sum>n = 100..999. count_odd_digits n) = 125"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_8.informal problem: How many three-digit numbers have all their digits odd? The final answer is 125.
